abstract.text: 29 30 31 2 35 Abstract Hubei province in China has completed cycle of quarantine-resumption in 23 rd 36 Janauary and 8 th April 2020, providing a unique opportunity as for now to assess its 37 intervention impact and the pattern of SARS-COV-2 transmission during the quarantine 38 period. In this study, we evaluate the impact of the metropolitan-wide quarantine on the trend 39 and transmission route of the COVID-19 epidemic in Hubei, China. The intervention reduces 40 more than 70% of new infections in both households and the public space, as well as the 41 deaths caused by COVID-19 pneumonia. Household transmission is the dominant route of 42 disease spread regardless of quarantine. This will provide important evidence and scientific 43 insights to other worldwide countries that are currently under quarantine. 44 45 Keywords. COVID-19; Metropolitan-wide quarantine; Public space; Households; 46 47 48 100 contacts was reduced by 80% (71-94%) in the public space [8] but increased by two times in 101 households [9] during the quarantine. Detailed model structure, parameters, and calibration 102 are shown in the Appendix. 103 104

In the presence of the quarantine, we estimated that 100,610 (95%CI: 82,326-118,900) 106 infections may have occurred and among which 68,975 (56,621-81,330) would be diagnosed, 107 and 3,252 (2,667-3,837) would have died, which are closely consistent with the observations. 108 This indicated that only 68.58% (65.58-71.58%) of infections could be diagnosed, whereas 109 31.42% (28.42-34.42%) of infections were spontaneously recovered and undocumented.

110 Among these infections, we estimated that the number of infections occurred in the public 111 space and households were 30,351 (24,931-35,771) and 70,262 (57,391-83,133), accounting 112 for 30.17% (29.96-30.38%) and 69.83% (69.62-70.04%) of all infections, respectively 128 129 Regardless of quarantine, household transmission appears to the dominant route of 130 transmission, although quarantine substantially increases the contribution of household 131 transmission to the epidemic. Household contacts are often without preventive measures and 132 prone to superspreading. It is estimated an average of 5.3 cases may subsequently be infected 133 if there is a single seeding case in the household [10]. Prevention of household transmission 134 is difficult, especially when infected individuals are in the latent period or habor an 135 asymptomatic infection. Regular cleaning with disinfectants and active screening of 136 household members may help to prevent the infection and facilitate early diagnosis.

body_text.text: We collected data on the number of cumulative confirmed cases and deaths from 15 th January 95 2020 to 8 th April 2020 from the Health Commission of Hubei Province [3] (Table S1) . We (Figure 1, Figure S4 ). If the quarantine had never been in place, the COVID-19 epidemic We estimated that the metropolitan-wide quarantine strategy implemented in Hubei province 126 might have reduced more than 70% of epidemic compared with the absence of the quarantine.

This is consistent with previous evaluations based on various modelling approaches [7] . This study has several limitations. First, we model the effects of metropolitan-wide 141 quarantine with a reduction in the effective contact rate. We cannot distinguish whether the 142 effects were due to media reports and voluntary isolation. Second, we assumed 100% 143 adherence to the social distancing policy during the quarantine, which may not be the case in We concluded that the metropolitan-wide quarantine in Hubei has greatly reduced the number 155 of new infections in the public space and, consequently, in households.

FIGREF0.text: new dynamic compartmental model involving two modes of transmission 52 (public space and households) is proposed to evaluate the impact of the 53 metropolitan-wide quarantine on the trend and transmission pattern of the 54 COVID-19 epidemic in Hubei, China. 55 The quarantine reduces more than 70% of new infections in both households and 56 the public space, as well as the deaths caused by COVID-19 pneumonia. 57 Household transmission is the dominant route of disease spread regardless of 58 quarantine. 59 The results will provide important evidence and scientific insights to other 60 worldwide countries that are currently under quarantine. st December 2019, a pneumonia case of unknown etiology from Wuhan, Hubei 66 Province, China was reported to the World Health Organization (WHO), which was later 67 confirmed as a new coronavirus disease (COVID-19) with infection of a novel coronavirus 68 named as "severe acute respiratory syndrome coronavirus 2" (SARS-CoV-2) [1]. As of 8 th 69 April 2020, more than 200 countries worldwide have reported over 1.35 million confirmed 70 cases and 79,000 deaths [2]. A total of 83,157 cases and 3,342 deaths were reported in China, 71and approximately 81% of (67,803) cases and 96% (3,215) of deaths were from the Hubei 72 Province[3].

FIGREF1.text: the spread of COVID-19, the Chinese government initiated an unprecedented 75 metropolitan-wide quarantine on 13 major cities in Hubei province since 23 rd January 2020, 76 which significantly reduced the movement of people by terminating most forms of 77 transportation [4][5]. The quarantine has substantially reduced social contacts in the public 78 space but increased contacts in households. The quarantine lasted for eleven weeks, and 79 Wuhan, the last city of Hubei province in quarantine, was eventually resumed its economic 80 activities and public transportation on 8 th April 2020. As for now, a major intervention in the 81 first epicenter of the COVID-19 epidemic has formally concluded. During this quarantine, a 82 WHO report [6] has shown that most (78-85%) of the transmissions in China had occurred in 83 a household setting. The completed cycle of quarantine-resumption of Hubei province 84 provides a unique opportunity to assess its intervention impact and the pattern of SARS-85 COV-2 transmission during the quarantine period. The preceding experiences in Hubei, 86 China, will provide important evidence and scientific insights to other worldwide countries 87 that are currently under quarantine.

Different from most existing models[7], we modelled two modes of 98 transmission, including social contacts in public space (e.g. public transportations, 99 supermarkets, offices, etc.) and households. This suggests that the 118 quarantine would prevent 79.27% (75.10-83.45%) of deaths, 87.08% (84.68-89.49%) and 119 71.84% (66.39-77.29%) of infections in public space and households, respectively. Despite 120 the reduction, household transmission accounts for a higher proportion (69.83%) of all 121 transmission compared with 51.51% in the absence of quarantine.

FIGREF4.text: 144 reality. The effect of policy on negative externalities such as fear and public disorder may 145 undermine the value of the intervention. Third, we assumed the quarantine has the same 146 impact on all 13 cities underwent quarantine. Fourth, we did not consider the effect of 147 asymptomatic infection, which may underestimate the number of infected cases. Fifth, we did 148 not consider nosocomial infections where more than 3000 medical staffs were infected during 149 the early stage of the epidemic. This transmission route can be considered as a part of 150 infections in public space and does not affect the main conclusions. Despite these limitations, 151 this study fills an important research gap by assessing the impact of the metropolitan-wide 152 quarantine on the trend and transmission route of the SARS-CoV-2 epidemic.153 154

All the authors contributed to writing the paper and agreed with manuscript results and conclusions.
